thread.title: Republic of Ireland 0-0 Wales: Hosts fail to take advantage of Neil Taylor's red card - 5 things we learned
thread.title_full: Republic of Ireland 0-0 Wales: Hosts fail to take advantage of Neil Taylor's red card - 5 things we learned

author: Alex Richards
title: Republic of Ireland 0-0 Wales: Hosts fail to take advantage of Neil Taylor's red card - 5 things we learned
text:
Neither side could claim three points in Dublin (Photo: REUTERS) Share Get   Thank you for subscribing!   
Wales and Ireland played out a hard-fought 0-0 draw in Dublin which does little to help the World Cup hopes of either. 
The game, played out in front of a boisterous atmosphere at the Aviva Stadium, ended with Wales hanging on and down to 10 men, after Neil Taylor's red card for a shocking challenge on Seamus Coleman. The Irish captain now looks set to miss the rest of 2017, with a horrific leg break. 
Before then, it had been a feisty affair, with Wales desperate for three points, having won only one of their four qualifiers so far. 
But on a night when Gareth Bale couldn't quite find his best, they were kept at arm's length by a well-drilled Ireland side - who themselves went close to winning it late on, through James McClean. 
Here are five things we learned... 1. Post-Euro struggles continue for Wales Wales have not found the balance right since the Euros (Photo: REUTERS) 
Heroes at Euro 2016, but now Wales face a real uphill struggle to claim a place at the World Cup next year. 
Chris Coleman's men are still to be beaten in qualifying, but have drawn four of their five matches, and continue to trail Ireland, Serbia and now Austria. 
Now heading into matches as favourites, Wales aren't quite finding the balance quite right. 
The surprise factor has now very much gone, and it's leaving them looking at a summer off in 2018, rather than one spent in Russia. 2. No club loyalties here Whelan and Allen, Stoke teammates, square up (Photo: Getty Images Europe) 
Joe Allen spoke in the build up to the game and said that he and Stoke teammate Glenn Whelan wouldn’t be giving an inch in their midfield battle. And he wasn’t wrong. 
On the stroke of half-time the man called ‘Jesus’ by his Wales pals flicked the ball past his club colleague and tried to retrieve it the other side. 
Only Whelan, and specifically his elbow, had other ideas; beaten, he hung it back and stealthily dropped the ex-Liverpool man. 
Understandably, Allen was furious. Whelan, comically, argued the toss. The two even went head to head as the referee blew for half-time. 
It was about as exciting as the first half got. 3. Bale's frustration Bale will now miss the trip to Serbia through suspension (Photo: 2017 Getty Images) 
Gareth Bale has done some job lifting Wales on his shoulders in the past 18 months or so, playing for the team and being THE reason why Coleman's outfit are greater than the sum of its parts. 
But, perhaps for the first time tonight, there were signs that it is starting to weigh down the Real Madrid superstar. 
Bale so often fills two roles in this Wales side; the chief creator and the main finisher. But with qualification not quite going to plan, the signs were there that he was becoming frustrated by those around him. 
A lunge at a clearing John O'Shea saw him booked in the second half, which now means he misses the game in Serbia. He could also have seen a second yellow for a challenge on McClean later on. 
That said, there was a moment late on when he went on a one-man mission and almost fired into the top corner from 25 yards, when surrounded by Irish defenders. 
However, it was a largely frustrating night for the Welsh ace. And that frustration is now showing. 4. Ireland have heart, but lack creation O'Neill and the Irish brain's trust need to find a little more creative spark (Photo: 2017 Getty Images) 
Martin O'Neill's men are well placed at the halfway mark in qualification, but know that with a little more ingenuity, they'd almost be booking their plane tickets to Russia. 
Ireland were all heart, all energy in attack, and organised well defensively. 
But in the absence of Robbie Brady and veteran playmaker Wes Hoolahan, they lacked a little bit of X factor. 
That's something that O'Neill could desperately do with finding. 5. Get well soon Seamus Seamus Coleman is taken off on a stretcher (Photo: PA Wire) 
Neil Taylor isn’t a dirty player. He's a solid, honest pro. 
But this was an awful tackle from the Aston Villa defender. 
Now Everton defender Seamus Coleman faces being out of action for a considerable period. It was little wonder Sky Sports in England and RTE in Ireland both refused to show a replay of the incident. 
It was a horrendous lunge from Taylor, that left him visibly upset as he walked off the pitch following his red card. 
Now the important thing isn't to vilify him, but rather to hope Coleman gets well soon. Player Ratings by Adrian Kajumba 
Ireland: Randolph 6; Coleman 7 (Christie 72, 6), O’Shea 6, Keogh 6, Ward 6; Hendrick 6, Whelan 6, Meyler 6 (McGeady 80, 7), McClean MOTM 8; Walters 6, Long 6. 
Unused: Westwood, Doyle, Doyle, Horgan, Christie, Egan, Hourihane, Hayes, O’Dowda, Pearce. 
Wales: Hennessey 6; Chester 6, Williams 7, Davies 7; Gunter 7, Allen 8, Ledley 6 (Richards 72, 6), Taylor 6; Bale 7, Ramsey 6; Robson-Kanu 5 (Vokes 46, 6). 
Unused: Ward, Fon Williams, King, MacDonald, Edwards, Wilson, Collins, Walsh, Bradshaw, Woodburn. poll loading Who is more likely to qualify for the World Cup in 2018? 0+ VOTES SO FAR
